articles.headline: Who Is a Public Servant? Borrowers Have a Lot Riding on the Answer
articles.snippet: Confusion over a program to forgive the student loan debt of public service workers is tripping up some people and throwing their lives into chaos.
articles.abstract: Confusion over a program to forgive the student loan debt of public service workers is tripping up some people and throwing their lives into chaos.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2007, a countdown of sorts began for workers in the federal public service loan forgiveness program.

articles.headline: Facebook Takes the Punches While Rest of Silicon Valley Ducks
articles.snippet: Google’s ad business is twice as big as Facebook’s. But executives at Google and other big tech companies have avoided intense scrutiny. For now.
articles.abstract: Google’s ad business is twice as big as Facebook’s. But executives at Google and other big tech companies have avoided intense scrutiny. For now.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Two pages of notes sitting in a binder in front of Mark Zuckerberg during his congressional testimony this week hinted at a message the Facebook chief executive rarely got a chance to deliver: We’re not the only ones.
articles.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Jack Nicas

articles.headline: China’s Communists Rewrite the Rules for Foreign Businesses
articles.snippet: The party is strengthening its influence — often gaining direct decision-making power — over the international firms doing business in China.
articles.abstract: The party is strengthening its influence — often gaining direct decision-making power — over the international firms doing business in China.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — One hammer and sickle at a time, the Communist Party is making its way deeper into everyday Chinese life — and that includes the foreign companies doing business there.

articles.headline: R.N.C. Official Who Agreed to Pay Playboy Model $1.6 Million Resigns
articles.snippet: The official, Elliott Broidy, quit amid news of a deal he struck with a woman who became pregnant during an affair. The payout was arranged by President Trump’s lawyer Michael D. Cohen.
articles.abstract: The official, Elliott Broidy, quit amid news of a deal he struck with a woman who became pregnant during an affair. The payout was arranged by President Trump’s lawyer Michael D. Cohen.
articles.lead_paragraph: A major donor with close ties to the White House resigned on Friday as deputy finance chairman of the Republican National Committee after the revelation that he had agreed to pay $1.6 million to a former Playboy model who became pregnant during an affair.
articles.byline: By Rebecca R. Ruiz and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: A Public Outcry Against a Wall Street Titan’s Name on a High School
articles.snippet: Stephen Schwarzman, the private equity billionaire, offered a Pennsylvania high school $25 million. He wanted his name and likeness all over the school.
articles.abstract: Stephen Schwarzman, the private equity billionaire, offered a Pennsylvania high school $25 million. He wanted his name and likeness all over the school.
articles.lead_paragraph: ABINGTON, Pa. — Stephen A. Schwarzman, the Wall Street billionaire, was prepared to cut a $25 million check to the high school he attended here in the 1960s, to help it pay for a huge renovation project.

articles.headline: In the #MeToo Era, France Struggles With Sexual Crimes Involving Minors
articles.snippet: A recent case involving an 11-year-old girl has given urgency to the government’s efforts to change laws to better protect minors. Critics say the changes don’t go far enough.
articles.abstract: A recent case involving an 11-year-old girl has given urgency to the government’s efforts to change laws to better protect minors. Critics say the changes don’t go far enough.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Having twice before run into an 11-year-old named Sarah in the neighborhood, the 28-year-old man chatted amiably with her and said he had something to show her at an apartment building nearby.
articles.byline: By Alissa J. Rubin and Elian Peltier

articles.headline: U.S., Britain and France Strike Syria Over Suspected Chemical Weapons Attack
articles.snippet: The strikes sought to punish the Syrian government after what Western officials said was a deadly chemical attack in a Damascus suburb that had been held by rebels.
articles.abstract: The strikes sought to punish the Syrian government after what Western officials said was a deadly chemical attack in a Damascus suburb that had been held by rebels.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States and European allies launched airstrikes on Friday night against Syrian research, storage and military targets as President Trump sought to punish President Bashar al-Assad for a suspected chemical attack near Damascus last weekend that killed more than 40 people.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Ben Hubbard

articles.headline: Weight Watchers Gets Its Own Makeover
articles.snippet: Can Mindy Grossman, an F.O.O. (Friend of Oprah), make the weight-loss company relevant in the 21st Century by turning it into a “wellness” company?
articles.abstract: Can Mindy Grossman, an F.O.O. (Friend of Oprah), make the weight-loss company relevant in the 21st Century by turning it into a “wellness” company?
articles.lead_paragraph: “I’m C.E.O., but I’m really just a big fan of everybody,” said Mindy Grossman, introducing herself at the Weight Watchers International headquarters in Manhattan. It was a brisk Wednesday afternoon in March and about 100 people, some beaming in from San Francisco, had gathered in a large, brightly lit room above what used to be known as the Ladies’ Mile of Sixth Avenue.

articles.headline: Pentagon Says Syria Strikes Hit ‘Heart’ of Chemical Weapons Program
articles.snippet: Warplanes and ships from the United States, Britain and France launched more than 100 missiles at three chemical weapons storage and research facilities near Damascus and Homs, officials said.
articles.abstract: Warplanes and ships from the United States, Britain and France launched more than 100 missiles at three chemical weapons storage and research facilities near Damascus and Homs, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defense Department officials said on Saturday that American-led strikes against Syria had taken out the “heart” of President Bashar al-Assad’s chemical weapons program, but acknowledged that the Syrian government most likely retained some ability to again attack its own people with chemical agents.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Ben Hubbard

articles.headline: ‘Mission Accomplished!’ But What Is the Mission in Syria?
articles.snippet: The strike on chemical arms sites reflected President Trump’s competing impulses: an effort to demonstrate strength countered by a view that involvement in the Middle East since the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, has been a waste.
articles.abstract: The strike on chemical arms sites reflected President Trump’s competing impulses: an effort to demonstrate strength countered by a view that involvement in the Middle East since the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, has been a waste.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On the morning after, President Trump declared success. The surgical strike against chemical weapons facilities in Syria had been executed perfectly, he said on Saturday. “Mission Accomplished!” he wrote on Twitter.

articles.headline: How Profiteers Lure Women Into Often-Unneeded Surgery
articles.snippet: An alliance of law firms, marketers, finance companies and doctors makes money by coaxing women to have their mesh implants removed.
articles.abstract: An alliance of law firms, marketers, finance companies and doctors makes money by coaxing women to have their mesh implants removed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jerri Plummer was at home in Arkansas, watching television with her three children, when a stranger called to warn that her life was in danger.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: A $76,000 Monthly Pension: Why States and Cities Are Short on Cash
articles.snippet: Governments are struggling as mounting pension obligations crowd out the rest of their budgets. Oregon faces a severe, self-inflicted crisis.
articles.abstract: Governments are struggling as mounting pension obligations crowd out the rest of their budgets. Oregon faces a severe, self-inflicted crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: A public university president in Oregon gives new meaning to the idea of a pensioner.

articles.headline: A Hard Lesson in Syria: Assad Can Still Gas His Own People
articles.snippet: The conflict in Syria has demonstrated a larger truth: While it is easy to blow up its chemical facilities, it is also relatively simple for the Assad government to reconstitute them elsewhere.
articles.abstract: The conflict in Syria has demonstrated a larger truth: While it is easy to blow up its chemical facilities, it is also relatively simple for the Assad government to reconstitute them elsewhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Syria shipped what it claimed was the last of its chemical weapons out of the country in 2014, John Kerry, the secretary of state at the time, declared that it showed that skillful diplomacy could achieve far more than attacks on a few facilities.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Ben Hubbard

articles.headline: Silicon Valley Venture Capitalists Prepare for an I.P.O. Wave
articles.snippet: With Dropbox and Spotify successfully going public, tech investors believe that a bonanza of initial public offerings is finally about to arrive.
articles.abstract: With Dropbox and Spotify successfully going public, tech investors believe that a bonanza of initial public offerings is finally about to arrive.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Jason Pressman spent Thursday morning cheering from the balcony of the New York Stock Exchange as shares of the software firm Zuora, which he backed in 2008, began trading.

articles.headline: Trump to Impose New Sanctions on Russia Over Support for Syria
articles.snippet: Nikki Haley, the ambassador to the United Nations, said Russian companies that have supported Syria’s chemical weapons would be targeted on Monday.
articles.abstract: Nikki Haley, the ambassador to the United Nations, said Russian companies that have supported Syria’s chemical weapons would be targeted on Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration plans to impose new sanctions against Russia on Monday to punish it for enabling the Syrian government’s use of chemical weapons in its civil war, the latest in a series of actions by both sides underscoring the deterioration in relations between Moscow and the West.

articles.headline: Comey, in Interview, Calls Trump ‘Morally Unfit’ and ‘Stain’ on All Around Him
articles.snippet: ABC News interviewed James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director, as he uses a publicity blitz for his memoir to raise alarms about Mr. Trump.
articles.abstract: ABC News interviewed James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director, as he uses a publicity blitz for his memoir to raise alarms about Mr. Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If there was any chance that President Trump and James B. Comey could have avoided all-out war, it ended Sunday night.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Wall Street Titan Takes Aim at Law That Tripped Him Up
articles.snippet: Maurice R. Greenberg wants to curb the Martin Act, the regulation that led to his ouster at A.I.G., as well as other state securities rules.
articles.abstract: Maurice R. Greenberg wants to curb the Martin Act, the regulation that led to his ouster at A.I.G., as well as other state securities rules.
articles.lead_paragraph: At 92, Maurice R. Greenberg is not done fighting.

articles.headline: Report for America Supports Journalism Where Cutbacks Hit Hard
articles.snippet: The service program promotes local newspapers by sending reporters away from big cities. Google has committed money and training.
articles.abstract: The service program promotes local newspapers by sending reporters away from big cities. Google has committed money and training.
articles.lead_paragraph: A group of journalists have decided to do something about the diminution of newsrooms at the local level. They’re making reporting part of a national service program.

articles.headline: After U.S. Strikes, Syria Returns to War as Usual
articles.snippet: The strikes were calibrated to keep the West from being dragged further into war. That left President Bashar al-Assad in power and Syria in its painful status quo.
articles.abstract: The strikes were calibrated to keep the West from being dragged further into war. That left President Bashar al-Assad in power and Syria in its painful status quo.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — As the dust settles from missile strikes launched by the United States and its allies against Syria over the weekend, very little has changed for most Syrians who have spent years suffering through their country’s civil war.

articles.headline: Employees Jump at Genetic Testing. Is That a Good Thing?
articles.snippet: Genetic disease risk screening is becoming a popular employee benefit. But the tests may not be all that beneficial for the general population, experts say.
articles.abstract: Genetic disease risk screening is becoming a popular employee benefit. But the tests may not be all that beneficial for the general population, experts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: Levi Strauss & Company introduced a novel benefit for employees at its San Francisco headquarters last fall: free genetic screening to assess their hereditary risks for certain cancers and high cholesterol.

articles.headline: ‘They Eat Money’: How Mandela’s Political Heirs Grow Rich Off Corruption
articles.snippet: Since apartheid ended, African National Congress leaders have siphoned off tens of billions of dollars. Will South Africa’s new government confront such epic graft?
articles.abstract: Since apartheid ended, African National Congress leaders have siphoned off tens of billions of dollars. Will South Africa’s new government confront such epic graft?
articles.lead_paragraph: VREDE, South Africa — With loudspeakers blaring, city officials drove across the black township’s dirt roads in a pickup truck, summoning residents to the town hall. The main guest was a local figure who had soared up the ranks of the governing African National Congress and come back with an enticing offer.
articles.byline: By Norimitsu Onishi and Selam Gebrekidan
